title: Court rejects ACCC's claim TPG misled customers
text:
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has lost its Federal Court case against TPG Telecom over allegations the company was misleading customers.

The ACCC filed the lawsuit in December, alleging TPG misled customers with a $20 "prepayment" fee that allowed the company to unfairly pocket "millions of dollars".

Justice David O'Callaghan dismissed the proceeding on Friday morning and ordered the ACCC to pay costs.

The case has no connection to Vodafone and TPG's challenge to the ACCC's decision to block a merger of two companies, hearings for which ended last week. A decision on that case is not due until February 2020.

The ACCC claimed TPG had advertised the $20 fee as a prepayment to cover unexpected costs such as overseas calls. However, if the fee was not used, the watchdog claimed TPG had failed to refund customers.

"A reasonable consumer would expect that this $20 payment would be refunded if it was not used, but in fact it is non-refundable. It is unacceptable that TPG only disclose this forfeiture in fine print," ACCC deputy chairman Delia Rickard said.
description: The competition regulator has lost its case against TPG Telecom over allegations the company was misleading customers.
